articles.title: SEC and Ripple End Appeals, Closing Landmark Crypto Case as XRP Soars
articles.author: Sebastian Sinclair
articles.summary: The SEC and Ripple Labs Inc. have formally closed their legal dispute, filing to end their respective appeals in the case over the sale of XRP tokens. The SEC sued Ripple in December 2020, alleging the company and two of its executives conducted an unregistered securities offering by selling XRP, the world's third-largest crypto by market capitalization. Ripple denied the allegations, arguing that XRP is not a security. In June, Ripple agreed to pay a $125 million civil penalty to the U.S. Treasury.

articles.title: BREAKING: The Ripple-SEC Lawsuit Is Over, XRP Skyrocketing! * 100PercentFedUp.com * by Noah
articles.summary: Noah Christopher owns XRP and he's been talking about it since 2017. The legal battle between Elizabeth Warren, Gary Gensler and the SEC against Ripple and XRP is finally over. Ripple has entered into a $200 million agreement to purchase Rail, a Toronto-based payments platform.

articles.title: Mamo Crypto Surge: 59% Gain & New ATH – $0.32 Next?
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: Mamo (MAMO) is bucking the trend with a 59.9% surge in the last week. The recent dip to $0.172 proved to be a crucial test of Mamo's liquidity, and the subsequent bullish response is a strong signal. Mamo reached a new all-time high (ATH) on July 16th, and its current market capitalization is $190 million. articles.title: Trump opens the door for crypto and private equity in your 401(k) retirement plan
articles.summary: President Trump signed an executive order on Thursday. It allows 401(k) accounts to invest in higher-risk assets, such as private equity, cryptocurrencies and real estate. articles.title: Crypto's real barrier isn't trust, it's understanding

Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer said the government shouldn't be making retirement investment decisions for hardworking Americans.

articles.title: Chinese Fraudsters Busted Withdrawing Money From Mule Accounts
articles.author: Jeff Tomas
articles.summary: Two Chinese men and a Thai woman were arrested at a shopping centre in Chiang Mai. They were collecting money from mule bank accounts linked to scams involving fake investments, purchases and other fraudulent transactions. Police seized 1.1 million baht in cash, 3 Thai bank books and 4 mobile phones. The suspects are Mr Qin Long, 29, Mr Zhang Luping, 30, and Ms Sudarat Aree, 40, both Chinese nationals. They came to Thailand on tourist visas about a month ago and their main job was to collect money from the mule accounts and withdraw it from ATMs as instructed.

articles.title: AI roadmap key to staving off challenges
articles.author: MA SI
articles.summary: It is crucial to promote a comprehensive roadmap for the development of artificial intelligence that prioritizes secure innovation, industry experts and company executives said on Wednesday. Luo Laijun, vice-chairman of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce, said: "Healthy AI development demands innovation as the primary driver, security as the nonnegotiable baseline, and universal benefit as our core value." Zhao Zhiguo, former chief engineer at the Ministry of Industry, Information Technology, said the integration of AI and cybersecurity is the era's defining challenge. Zhou Hongyi, founder of Chinese internet enterprise 360 Security Group, warned of the limitations of generative AI.
